content: The Act may be cited as the "Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008". The Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008 emphasizes the importance of experienced counsel, protecting privileged communications, and enhancing compliance programs through effective internal investigations. The Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008 emphasizes the importance of protecting privileged communications and enhancing compliance programs through effective internal investigations. Prosecutors and government officials can conduct their work while respecting attorney-client privilege and individual rights. Government officials can conduct their work while respecting attorney-client privilege and individual rights, as demonstrated by the ban on demands for privileged materials in the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The Department of Justice and other agencies have policies that undermine the adversarial system of justice by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege to avoid sanctions. The policies implemented by government agencies are encroaching on constitutional rights and legal protections of employees, by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege to avoid indictment. An indictment can have severe consequences on an organization, potentially hindering its ability to survive post-indictment or dispute charges at trial. The purpose of this Act is to set clear limits on government agencies' waiver demands, ensuring that attorney-client privilege and legal protections of employees are preserved. The Act emphasizes that attorney-client privilege and other legal doctrines should not be used to conceal wrongdoing or evade the law. The Act aims to set clear limits on government agencies to preserve attorney-client privilege and legal protections for employees, preventing these privileges from being used to hide wrongdoing or evade the law. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF ATTORNEY-CLIENT PRIVILEGE OR ADVANCEMENT OF COUNSEL FEES AS ELEMENTS OF COOPERATION. The text chunk discusses the preservation of attorney-client privilege in investigations and enforcement matters regarding organizations. It defines attorney-client privilege as governed by common law and the Federal Rules of Evidence. The term 'attorney work product' refers to materials prepared by an attorney in anticipation of litigation, containing their mental impressions, conclusions, opinions, or legal theories. The term 'organization' excludes a continuing criminal enterprise. The term 'organization' excludes certain groups like continuing criminal enterprises, groups primarily focused on illegal money acquisition, and terrorist organizations. In any Federal investigation or enforcement matter, an agent or attorney cannot demand an organization to waive attorney-client privilege or work product protections. In Federal investigations, it is prohibited to demand, reward, or threaten an organization or its employees to waive attorney-client privilege or work product protections. In Federal investigations, agents or attorneys of the United States are prohibited from demanding, rewarding, or threatening organizations or their employees to waive attorney-client privilege or work product protections. In Federal investigations, agents or attorneys of the United States are prohibited from considering certain conduct when making charging or enforcement decisions related to organizations or their employees. The attorney-client privilege and attorney work product doctrine are factors that cannot be considered in Federal investigations when making charging or enforcement decisions related to organizations or their employees. The conduct described in this subparagraph includes asserting attorney-client privilege, providing legal counsel or financial support for employees, and participating in joint defense agreements.
